__________________________________
BUSINESS ALERT
from The Wall Street Journal


Dec. 20, 2001

Argentina's president resigned, a high-ranking official said. The end of De
la Rua's two-year term, amid violent reaction to his handling of a deepening
financial crisis, came hours after the country's economy minister stepped
down.

For more information, see:
http://interactive.wsj.com/articles/SB1008839567321991160.htm

body:
<email>
From: Emily Langton <emily.langton@olddictionary.com>
To: Hiro Nakamura <hiro.nakamura@origamimaster.com>
Subject: RE: Collaboration on an article about paper and folding

Hi Hiro,

Thank you so much for agreeing to collaborate on this article. I'm thrilled to have your expertise on board!

I've attached a draft of my initial research on the linguistic roots of words related to paper and folding. As you'll see, I've focused primarily on Old English and Proto-Germanic terms, but I believe that incorporating the history and techniques of origami could help shed light on how these words have evolved over time.

Please let me know if you have any suggestions or additional resources that could help strengthen the article. I'm particularly interested in learning more about the specific terms used in origami and how they've influenced the English language.

I'm available to discuss our ideas further next week, if that works for you. Please let me know what day and time would be convenient for you.

Thank you again for your willingness to collaborate on this project. I'm excited to see where our combined knowledge will take us!

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

Let's have Matt start on the following:

Database for hourly storage activity on Socal.  Begin forecasting hourly and 
daily activity by backing out receipts, using ISO load actuals and backing 
out real time imports to get in state gen numbers for gas consumption, and 
then using temps to estimate core gas load.  Back testing once he gets 
database created should help him forecast core demand.

Update Socal and PG&E forecast sheets.  Also, break out new gen by EPNG and 
TW pipelines.

Mike

body:
<email>
From: Sarah Johnson <sarah.johnson@email.com>
To: Emily Davis <emily.davis@email.com>
Subject: Thank you for the informative workshop!

Dear Emily,

I wanted to thank you for the wonderful presentation on vaccinations during pregnancy at the community center last week. As a homeschooling parent, I'm always looking for reliable information to help me make the best decisions for my family's health.

I'm currently pregnant with my second child and have a 4-year-old daughter. I was wondering if you could provide some guidance on how to manage the new baby's vaccination schedule while ensuring my daughter's health and homeschooling routine are not disrupted. I would greatly appreciate any insights you could share.

Thank you for your time and expertise.

Best regards,
Sarah
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@foodscience.com>
To: David Lee <david.lee@softdev.com>
Subject: Catching up and a potential collaboration

Hey David,

It's been a while since we last talked! I hope you're doing well and enjoying your work at SoftDev Solutions. I'm reaching out because I'm working on an exciting project at FoodScience Innovations, and I think you might be the perfect person to help me with it.

We're developing a new food product that's both healthy and delicious, and I need help creating a software application to track the chemical composition of the ingredients and the final product. Your expertise in designing and implementing service-oriented applications using Microsoft technologies would be invaluable to this project.

Would you be interested in meeting up for coffee sometime to discuss this further? I'd love to catch up and see if we can collaborate on this project.

Let me know your thoughts!

Best,
Emily
label: research

Subject: El Paso Energy Corporation Reports Record Second Quarter Earnings 
Per Share


http://biz.yahoo.com/prnews/000711/tx_el_paso_2.html

Tuesday July 11, 5:42 pm Eastern Time
Company Press Release
SOURCE: El Paso Energy Corporation
El Paso Energy Corporation Reports Record Second Quarter Earnings Per Share
HOUSTON, July 11 /PRNewswire/ -- El Paso Energy Corporation (NYSE: EPG
<http://finance.yahoo.com/q?s=epg&d=t> - news </n/e/epg.html>) today
announced second quarter 2000 adjusted diluted earnings per share of $0.69,
an increase of 73 percent over second quarter 1999 adjusted diluted earnings
per share of $0.40. The second quarter 2000 results exclude $0.13 per share
of one-time merger-related items. Diluted average common shares outstanding
for the second quarter 2000 totaled 242 million. Consolidated adjusted
earnings before interest expense and income taxes (EBIT) for the second
quarter increased by 55 percent to $408 million, compared with $263 million
in the year-ago period.
EBIT from the company's non-regulated businesses more than tripled in the
quarter to $246 million, and represented 60 percent of consolidated EBIT.
``Outstanding growth in Merchant Energy and continued strong performance in
our other non-regulated segments produced these record results,'' said
William A. Wise, president and chief executive officer of El Paso Energy
Corporation. ``Reflecting our long-standing strategy of building a portfolio
of flexible gas and power assets, Merchant Energy's earnings continued to
accelerate in the second quarter.''
For the first six months of 2000, adjusted diluted earnings per share
increased 84 percent to $1.40 per share, compared with $0.76 for the first
six months of 1999. Consolidated EBIT for the six months, excluding
non-recurring items, increased 55 percent to $798 million compared with $515
million in the year-ago period.
Second Quarter Business Segment Results
The Merchant Energy segment reported record EBIT of $152 million in the
second quarter 2000, compared with $6 million in the same period last year
and $50 million in the first quarter 2000. The physical and financial gas
and power portfolio developed over the past several years is creating
significant value in the current volatile energy environment. Enhanced
trading opportunities around our asset positions, continued strong wholesale
customer business, and management fees from Project Electron (the company's
off-balance sheet vehicle for power generation investments) all contributed
to the record second-quarter performance.
The Production segment reported a 30-percent increase in second quarter EBIT
to $52 million compared with $40 million a year ago, reflecting higher
realized gas and oil prices and lower operating costs following the
reorganization of its business in 1999. Weighted average realized prices for
the quarter were $2.26 per million cubic feet (MMcf) of natural gas and
$19.21 per barrel of oil, up 12 percent and 29 percent, respectively, from
the year-ago levels. Average natural gas production totaled 512 MMcf per day
and oil production averaged 14,275 barrels per day.
The Field Services segment reported second quarter EBIT of $30 million,
nearly double an adjusted $16 million in 1999. The increase was due
primarily to higher realized gathering and processing margins, together with
the acquisition of an interest in the Indian Basin processing plant in March
2000. Second quarter gathering and treating volumes averaged 4.1 trillion
Btu per day (TBtu/d), while processing volumes averaged 1.1 TBtu/d.
Coming out of one of the warmest winters on record, the Natural Gas
Transmission segment reported second quarter EBIT of $190 million compared
with an adjusted $187 million a year ago, reflecting the realization of cost
savings from the Sonat merger. Overall system throughput averaged 11.3
TBtu/d. During the quarter, Southern Natural Gas received Federal Energy
Regulatory Commission approval of its comprehensive rate case settlement
filed in March.
The International segment reported second quarter EBIT of $12 million
compared with $16 million in 1999. Higher equity income from projects in
Brazil and Argentina largely offset lower equity earnings from the company's
investment in the Philippines.
Telecom Update
``We have made substantial progress in the development of our
telecommunications business, El Paso Global Networks,'' said William A.
Wise. ``Reflecting our market-centric approach to developing new businesses,
we have named Greg G. Jenkins, the current president of El Paso Merchant
Energy, to head our telecommunications business. Our expertise in building
businesses in rapidly commoditizing markets, as demonstrated by our Merchant
Energy success, provides us with a key competitive entry point in the
telecommunications marketplace.''
Quarterly Dividend
The Board of Directors declared a quarterly dividend of $0.206 per share on
the company's outstanding common stock. The dividend will be payable October
2, 2000 to shareholders of record as of the close of business on September
1, 2000. There were 237,786,853 outstanding shares of common stock entitled
to receive dividends as of June 30, 2000.
With over $19 billion in assets, El Paso Energy Corporation provides
comprehensive energy solutions through its strategic business units:
Tennessee Gas Pipeline Company, El Paso Natural Gas Company, Southern
Natural Gas Company, El Paso Merchant Energy Company, El Paso Energy
International Company, El Paso Field Services Company, and El Paso
Production Company. The company owns North America's largest natural gas
pipeline system, both in terms of throughput and miles of pipeline, and has
operations in natural gas transmission, merchant energy services, power
generation, international project development, gas gathering and processing,
and gas and oil production. On May 5, the stockholders of both El Paso
Energy and The Coastal Corporation overwhelmingly voted in favor of merging
the two organizations. The combined company will have assets of $35 billion
and be one of the world's leading integrated energy companies. The merger is
expected to close in the fourth quarter of this year, concurrent with the
completion of regulatory reviews. Visit El Paso Energy's web site at
www.epenergy.com <http://www.epenergy.com>.
Cautionary Statement Regarding Forward-Looking Statements
This release includes forward-looking statements and projections, made in
reliance on the safe harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation
Reform Act of 1995. The company has made every reasonable effort to ensure
that the information and assumptions on which these statements and
projections are based are current, reasonable, and complete. However, a
variety of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from the
projections, anticipated results or other expectations expressed in this
release. While the company makes these statements and projections in good
faith, neither the company nor its management can guarantee that the
anticipated future results will be achieved. Reference should be made to the
company's (and its affiliates') Securities and Exchange Commission filings
for additional important factors that may affect actual results.

body:
<email>
From: John Smith <john.smith@university.edu>
To: Jane Doe <jane.doe@university.edu>
Subject: Language tips for my research trip to Asia

Hi Jane,

I hope you're doing well. As you might know, I'm planning a research trip to Asia to study Homo erectus fossils and collaborate with colleagues from various institutions. Since English is not the first language for many of my colleagues, I was wondering if you could provide me with some tips on how to effectively communicate with them. Any advice on language learning resources or strategies would be greatly appreciated.

Best regards,
John

body:
<email>
From: Erik Lindström <erik.lindstrom@solna.se>
To: Karin Andersson <kandersson@lunduniversity.se>
Subject: RE: Collaboration Opportunity: Swedish Language and Environmental Science

Hej Karin,

Thank you for your prompt response. I am happy to confirm that I can meet on Tuesday, March 15th, at 10:00 AM at the university campus. I look forward to discussing the project in more detail and meeting the students who will be working with me.

I have been doing some more research on acid rain and its effects on plant growth since we last communicated, and I am excited to share my findings with you and your students. I believe that this project will not only help me improve my Swedish language skills but also deepen my understanding of the environmental issues we are facing.

Please let me know if there is anything I should prepare or bring to the meeting. I am eager to get started on this collaboration and contribute to the success of the project.

Thank you again for this opportunity, and I look forward to meeting you next week.

Best regards,
Erik Lindström
label: research

body:
<email>
From: David Harrison <david.harrison@maritimehistory.org>
To: Sarah Thompson <sarah.thompson@sciencejournal.com>
Subject: RE: Bermuda Triangle article - need your expertise!

Hello Sarah,

It's great to hear from you! I'm glad you reached out about this topic. The Bermuda Triangle has always been a fascinating subject, and I've come across some interesting historical accounts that might be relevant to your article.

I recently stumbled upon a lesser-known maritime mystery involving the disappearance of a ship in the early 19th century. The circumstances surrounding the incident are quite puzzling and could make for an interesting case study. I'd be happy to share more details if you're interested.

Additionally, I think a collaboration between our fields could yield some exciting results. Perhaps we could work together to investigate some of these unexplained phenomena using a combination of historical research and scientific analysis.

Let me know your thoughts, and feel free to reach out if you'd like to discuss this further.

Best,
David
label: research

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: John Arnold
X-To: Greg Whalley
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Dec2000\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Arnold-J
X-FileName: Jarnold.nsf

---------------------- Forwarded by John Arnold/HOU/ECT on 08/08/2000 05:54 
PM ---------------------------


"Zerilli, Frank" <fzerilli@POWERMERCHANTS.COM> on 08/08/2000 08:17:19 AM
To: "David D'alessandro (E-mail)" <DDALESSA@SEMPRATRADING.COM>, 
"'jarnold@enron.com'" <jarnold@enron.com>
cc: "Glynn,Kevin" <kglynn@POWERMERCHANTS.COM>, "Wolkwitz, Rick" 
<rwolkwitz@POWERMERCHANTS.COM>, "Kelly, Joseph" <jkelly@POWERMERCHANTS.COM> 
Subject: Reuters Story on E-Exchange


By Fiona O'Brien
   LONDON, Aug 8 (Reuters) - The head of the largest yet Internet
exchange for energy products said it will combine traditional anonymity
with transparency to give traders a better overview of market activity.
   The InterContinentalExchange (ICE), an Atlanta-based venture
initiated by seven major oil companies and banks is due to launch August
24 for trade in precious metals swaps, with energy products trade to go
live soon afterwards.
   While market transparency will increase as dealers used to
over-the-counter (OTC) telephone-based market trade on a screen, users
of the ICE will remain nameless up until the point of trade, Jeffrey
Sprecher, ICE's chief executive officer told Reuters in an interview.
   "As soon as you hit the deal, the system reveals both
counterparties," he said. "The real strength is that you (still) get the
ability to manage your own counterparties.
   "You can list all of the people you want to do business with and put
in the credit terms under which you will do business."
   This information will then be processed by what Sprecher called a
"giant matrix" within the system.
   "(At the moment) people in the over-the-counter market aren't sure
they have ever seen the entire market," he said.
   "(On the ICE), deals you can do will appear in white and deals you
can't do will be in grey, but you can see the entire market."
   Giving players a fuller complement of figures than they are currently
aware of in a telephone-dominated market should increase market
transparency, as they can keep abreast of the activities of dealers who
fall outside their own trading criteria, Sprecher said.
   The exchange is expected to function in real time around the clock
and will be accessible via the public internet or a private network
connection.
   Initial liquidity will be provided by founder members BP Amoco
<BPA.L>, Deutsche Bank <DBKGn.DE>, Goldman Sachs <GS.N>, Morgan Stanley
Dean Witter <MWD.N>, Royal Dutch/Shell <RD.AS><SHEL.L>, Societe Generale
<SOGN.PA> and TotalfinaElf <TOTF.PA>.
   Shell runs the industry's largest international oil trading operation
and Goldman Sachs' J.Aron commodities arm last year was dominant
internationally in unregulated OTC oil derivatives.
   Late in July the original cast was joined by six gas and power
companies, American Electric Power <AEP.N,> Utilicorp's Aaquila Energy
<UCU.N,> Duke Energy <DUK.N,> El Paso Energy <EPG.N>, Reliant Energy
<REI.N> and Southern Company Energy Marketing <SO.N>.
   Sprecher said continued liquidity would be ensured by the fact that
the founding members will pay fees even if they do not trade and will
face additional penalties if they fail to live up to their commitment to
trade a minimum volume.

   TRADERS STILL TO DO OWN CLEARING
   As well as increasing awareness of market moves, Sprecher believes
trading over the Internet could boost trading profits.
"The economics (of the system) will be driven by the fact that a
paperless back office can really save a lot of money," he said.
   However such savings on trading the ICE appear some way off given
that dealers will initially have to continue using their own clearing
systems, as they do in current OTC systems.
   Under the ICE, once a deal has been struck both counterparties will
receive an electronic deal ticket which will then go through those
players' own risk management systems.
   But the exchange is eager to look at ways of introducing its own
clearing system.
  "No one really knows how at the moment," Sprecher said. "There might
be some hybrid between traditional exchange clearing and what now exists
peer to peer."
  In terms of participation costs, no membership fees will be incurred
except those associated with trading. Membership is open to any
commercial market participant.
   Each product will have its own published commission schedule, which
Sprecher assessed at "slightly below the best prices someone would pay
in the voice broker business".  ((London newsroom +44 20 7542 7930)

body:
<email>
From: Alex Chen <achen@emergencyresponse.gov>
To: Jordan Reeves <jreeves@law.university.edu>
Subject: Urgent legal consultation needed for radiological disaster response case

Dear Jordan,

I hope this email finds you well. I am reaching out to you today because I urgently need your expertise in constitutional law and judicial process. I am currently working on a high-profile case involving the legal implications of a radiological disaster response, and I believe that your insights would be invaluable in ensuring that our efforts are legally sound and effective.

As you may know, there is an upcoming court hearing that will determine the fate of our response efforts. We are facing significant pressure from a powerful government agency to achieve a specific outcome, and I am concerned that this may compromise our ability to uphold the rule of law and protect the public interest.

I would be grateful if you could provide your expert opinion on the legal and constitutional issues at play in this case, as well as your recommendations for how we should proceed. I understand that this is a highly sensitive matter, and I assure you that your input will be treated with the utmost confidentiality.

Please let me know if you are available to discuss this further. I am happy to provide you with any additional information or documentation that you may need.

Thank you in advance for your time and consideration.

Best regards,
Alex Chen
Emergency Management Specialist
National Radiological Disaster Response Agency

body:
<email>
From: Alex Thompson <alex.thompson@email.com>
To: Jordan Lee <jordan.lee@email.com>
Subject: RE: Cassini's Grand Finale

Hey Jordan,

Thanks for your insightful response. I completely agree with you on the significance of Cassini's findings, especially regarding Enceladus and Titan. It's incredible to think that these distant moons could potentially harbor life.

As for my project, it's coming along quite well. I've been analyzing the data from Cassini's rings observations and trying to create a comprehensive model of their composition and structure. It's challenging work, but I'm excited about the potential discoveries that could come out of it.

Speaking of which, I recently came across an article about the upcoming total solar eclipse that will be visible in our region. I was thinking of making a trip to see it and was wondering if you'd be interested in joining me. It could be a great opportunity to witness a celestial event together and bond over our shared passion for astronomy.

Let me know what you think!

Best,
Alex
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Arianna Salazar <arianna.salazar@astroethics.org>
To: Dr. Mikhail Sokolov <mikhail.sokolov@history.edu>
Subject: Following up from the Interdisciplinary Conference

Dear Dr. Sokolov,

I hope this email finds you well. I enjoyed our conversation at the Interdisciplinary Conference last month and found your presentation on resource management in socialist countries fascinating. I've been thinking about the potential for a collaborative project exploring the historical lessons that can be applied to sustainable space exploration and settlement.

I believe that your expertise in the history of communism and socialism could provide valuable insights into how different ideological frameworks have shaped resource management and environmental policies in the past. By understanding these historical contexts, we may be able to develop more sustainable and equitable approaches to space exploration and settlement.

I would love to discuss this idea further with you. Would you be available for a virtual meeting in the coming weeks to explore potential avenues for collaboration?

Best regards,
Arianna Salazar
label: research

rules to a game:
You flip a coin. If you get tails you win 0.  if you get heads, i give you
$1.  Keep flipping until you get a tails, at which point you walk away with
the money.  however, each heads you get after the first you double your
money.  So if you flip heads 3 times and then tails, you get $4.  What's
you bid/offer on playing this game?  (would you pay $.5 to play? $1? $2?
what you charge me play against you?)

body:
Message-ID: <4242418.1075857578297.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Fri, 14 Jul 2000 10:46:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: john.arnold@enron.com
To: frank.hayden@enron.com
Subject: Re: Market Opinion about AGA's
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: John Arnold
X-To: Frank Hayden
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Dec2000\Notes Folders\All documents
X-Origin: Arnold-J
X-FileName: Jarnold.nsf

Interesting observation...but I'm not sure I agree.   I think consensus 
opinion is that anything under 2.7 TCF is very dangerous entering the 
winter.  A month ago, analysts were predicting we would end the injection 
season with around 2.6 - 2.7 in the ground. With the most recent AGA, those 
projections seem to be closer to 2.7.  With supply of gas very inelastic to 
price in the short and medium term, you must look at the demand side of the 
equation.  The market is trying to price out the right amount of demand 
(mostly through lost industrial load and fuel switching) such that supplies 
will be stored rather than burned.  Each AGA number is another data point as 
to whether nat gas is high enough to price out enough demand to reach a 
comfortable level in storage entering the winter.   A low AGA number 
indicates we haven't priced out enough demand and the market must go up.  
Certainly, the 97 throws a curve in the bull argument, but the number  may be 
a function of very mild weather, a four day holiday weekend, and reporting 
noise rather than indicative of a structural shift in the supply/demand 
equilibrium.  We'll know a lot more as the next two weeks' numbers come out.  
If we get two low injections, watch out.


   
	Enron North America Corp.
	
	From:  Frank Hayden @ ENRON                           07/12/2000 04:39 PM
	

To: John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc:  
Subject: Market Opinion about AGA's


	

John,
I think the AGA's are not as important to bulls as to bears.  In the 
beginning of the season, AGA's were  very important in framing the bull 
case.  The current expectation is that we will go into the winter under 
stored.  I don't believe any additional AGA news can significantly change 
that expectation. 

However, I believe Bears, as evidenced today, will feed more heavily off of 
bearish AGA news, than bulls will off bullish AGA news.

At this juncture, I believe that the most potent bullish news has to come 
from the physical market and weather. 

I hope you don't mind me expressing my view point on this issue.

Thanks,
Frank

To: Dr. Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@renewableenergy.org>
Subject: Science Fair Invitation

Dear Michael,

I hope you're doing well. I have an exciting opportunity that I wanted to share with you.

My school is organizing a Science Fair next month, and I immediately thought of you when we were discussing potential guest speakers. I believe that your work in renewable energy would be a fantastic inspiration for our students. If you're interested, I would love to invite you to give a presentation at the event.

I understand that your schedule might be busy, but if you're able to join us, I think it would be a wonderful opportunity for our students to learn from a leading expert in the field. Please let me know if you would like to participate, and I can provide you with more details about the event.

I look forward to hearing back from you!

Best regards,
Emily

A vertebrate paleontologist with a focus on teaching and academic publishing, particularly in the fields of early reptiles, Triassic dinosaurs, and macroevolution.ic.edu>

Subject: RE: Our upcoming presentation at the SA Paleontological Society conference

Hi Michael,

I hope you're doing well! I've been looking over the feedback we received from the conference organizers regarding our presentation. They've requested that we provide a more detailed explanation of our phylogenetic analysis methods and how they differ from previous studies.

I think this is a great opportunity for us to showcase the novelty of our approach and emphasize the significance of our findings. Would you be willing to take the lead on revising this section of our presentation? Your expertise in this area will be invaluable in making our case to the audience.

Emily

PROS Announces Energy Profit Optimization Workshop Agenda

Workshops Target Storage, Trading, and Transportation

October 26, 2001-Houston- PROS Revenue Management, the world's leader in pricing and revenue optimization science and software, and the pioneer and dominant provider of revenue management to the airline and energy industries, today announced the industry-leading agenda published for its Energy Profit Optimization Workshop, being held November 5 at PROS Headquarters located in Houston, TX.

The following agenda is an overview of the Energy Workshop Program.

8:00am  Registration & Continental Breakfast

?	Introduction to Energy Profit Optimization, Matt Johnson, Senior Vice President, energy group at PROS Revenue Management, 10 years experience with revenue optimization
?	Applying Profit Optimization to the Natural Gas Industry, Albert Viscio, Senior Accenture partner focusing on pricing and revenue optimization strategy and best practices in energy, utilities, and chemical industries
?	Storage Trading: A Strategic Perspective, Soli Forouzan, Former Vice President Risk and Director of Storage Trading at PG&E
?	Planning for a Profit Optimization System, Kurt King, Managing Director, Commercial Technology at Duke Energy
?	Optimized Dynamic Commerce, Glen Shrank, Industry leader of Optimized Dynamic Commerce Tools that are at the heart of ERCOT auction pricing engines for both Reliant Energy and TXU
?	Simultaneous Workshops
   Workshop 1: Marketing & Trading
   Workshop 2: Asset Valuation & Optimization
   Workshop 3: Pipelines

4:00pm  Adjourn, reception following

"PROS has selected some of the top leaders in the energy industry to participate" says Matt Johnson, senior vice president of PROS' energy group.  "The use of pricing optimization and revenue management solutions is essential for the forward-thinking energy industry companies to survive and prosper, and our workshop will show this to our interested participants."

This workshop is free of charge.  For more information, registration, and a complete agenda, please check the PROS Web site at http://www.prosRM.com/energy/workshop.htm.

--------------------------------------------------

PROS Revenue Management is the world's leader in pricing and revenue optimization solutions and the pioneer and dominant provider of revenue management to the airline and energy industry. PROS provides system solutions to the airline, energy, cargo, rail, healthcare, and broadcast industries, and has licensed over 235 systems to more than 95 clients in 39 countries. PROS' clients include 15 of the top 25 carriers in the airline industry.

The PROS mission is to maximize the revenue of each client using PROS' world-leading revenue management science, systems solutions, and best practices business consulting. PROS' clients report annual incremental revenue increases of 6-8% as a result of revenue management. PROS' solutions forecast demand, optimize inventory, and provide dynamic pricing to maximize revenue.

Founded in 1985 in Houston, PROS Revenue Management has a six-year compounded revenue growth of 40%, in large part due to the intellectual capital of its staff. Nearly half of PROS' professional staff has advanced degrees and the staff speaks a cumulative total of 26 languages. The company is profitable with Year 2000 revenue of $29 million. For more information on PROS Revenue Management, please visit www.prosRM.com or call 713-335-5151.

Contact:
Candy Haase - VP Marketing
713-335-5151 / 713-335-8144 - fax


If you no longer wish to receive information about PROS Revenue Management, please click on "Reply" and type "Unsubscribe" in the subject line.

body:
<email>
From: Ahmed Mwangi <amwangi@college.ac.ke>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@university.edu>
Subject: RE: Excited to collaborate!

Hi Emily,

I'm so glad you reached out! I've been thinking about our conversations as well and I'm really intrigued by the idea of exploring the connections between our fields. I think a collaboration could be really productive and lead to some exciting new insights.

I've been reading your paper on the history of the discovery of DNA and I'm struck by the way scientific discoveries can reshape our understanding of the world in much the same way that linguistic developments can. There seem to be some really interesting parallels there.

I would definitely be interested in working together on this project. I think we could start by outlining our main arguments and gathering evidence to support them. Perhaps we could each take the lead on a different section of the paper based on our respective areas of expertise.

I'm excited to dive deeper into this topic with you and see where it leads. Let me know what you think about the next steps.

Best,
Ahmed

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@ridgemontschools.org>
To: David Thompson <dthompson@pumptechsolutions.com>
Subject: Request for information on pump technology in World War II

Dear Mr. Thompson,

I hope this email finds you well. My name is Emily Johnson, and I am a high school social studies teacher at Ridgemont High School. A mutual acquaintance of ours, Sarah Nguyen, suggested that I reach out to you regarding a lesson plan I am developing on the role of technology in World War II.

I am particularly interested in learning more about the advancements in pump technology during this period and how they contributed to the war effort. I believe that including this information in my curriculum would provide my students with a unique perspective on the impact of the war on engineering and technological progress.

Would you be willing to share some insights on this topic? I would greatly appreciate any information you could provide, such as specific examples of pump technologies used during the war, their applications, and the impact of these advancements on modern engineering practices.

Thank you for considering my request. I understand that you have a busy schedule, and I would be grateful for any time you can spare to assist me in this endeavor.

Best regards,
Emily Johnson

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@publicradio.org>
To: David Lee <david.lee@dentaltech.com>
Subject: Interested in featuring your work on our radio segment

Hi David,

I hope you're doing well! I wanted to follow up on our recent conversation about your work in dental technology and research. I think our listeners would be really interested in learning more about the latest advancements in this field and how they could potentially impact public health.

Would you be open to providing some information and resources for a radio segment we're putting together on innovative healthcare technologies? I'd be happy to discuss this further and answer any questions you may have.

Looking forward to hearing from you!

Best,
Emily

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Bcc: mike.grigsby@enron.com
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: Ned Higgins
X-cc: Mike Grigsby
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_June2001\Notes Folders\Sent
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

Ned,

Regarding the Waha storage, the west desk does not have a strong need for 
this storage but we are always willing to show a bid based on the current 
summer/winter spreads and cycling value.  The following assumptions were made 
to establish our bid:  5% daily injection capacity, 10% daily withdrawal 
capacity, 1% fuel (injection only), 0.01/MMBtu variable injection and 
withdrawal fees.  Also an undiscounted  June 01 to January 02 spread of $0.60 
existed at the time of this bid.

Bid for a 1 year storage contract beginning June 01 based on above 
assumptions:  $0.05/ MMBtu/Month ($0.60/Year).  Demand charges only.

I am not sure if this is exactly what you need or not.  Please call or email 
with comments.

Phillip Allen

Subject: Implementation of the Gas Message Board Application

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Bcc: laura.harder@enron.com, kimberly.brown@enron.com, airam.arteaga@enron.com
X-From: Ina Rangel
X-To: Tom Donohoe, Kelli Stevens, Jason Williams, Patrice L Mims, Kevin Ruscitti, Martin Cuilla, Geoff Storey, Hunter S Shively, Andrew H Lewis, Sylvia S Pollan, Sandra F Brawner, Peter F Keavey, Brad McKay, Robin Barbe, John Craig Taylor, Susan W Pereira, Andrea Ring, Scott Neal, Dick Jenkins, Scott Hendrickson, Dan Junek, Jared Kaiser, Tammi DePaolis, Judy Townsend, Chris Germany, Jay Reitmeyer, Kenneth Shulklapper, Matthew Lenhart, Steven P South, Jane M Tholt, Monique Sanchez, Keith Holst, Phillip K Allen, Mike Grigsby, Carey M Metz, Stacey Neuweiler, Liz Bellamy, Jim Schwieger, Thomas A Martin, Greg McClendon, Elsa Villarreal, Daren J Farmer, Lauri A Allen, Edward D Gottlob, Gary W Lamphier, Danny Conner, John Arnold, Mike Maggi, Larry May
X-cc: Laura Harder, Kimberly Brown, Airam Arteaga
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \John_Arnold_Dec2000\Notes Folders\All documents
X-Origin: Arnold-J
X-FileName: Jarnold.nsf

Please see the following instructions for the new messenging board.  If you 
have any trouble entering into this site, please let me know.  Everyone 
should now be setup and ready to go. You will have to add this site to one of 
your favorites.  

The Gas Message Board application can run on both IE5.0 and IE5.5 now. 

Attached is the URL for user to run the application.

http://gasmsgboard.dev.corp.enron.com

Please feel free to forward above URL to people who like to test the 
application. 

Here is the steps they should do:

1) Launch Internet Explorer

2) Type: http://gasmsgboard.dev.corp.enron.com (or just open this email and 
click on above URL)

3) Users should see the messages if there is any new messages for today. If 
they don't see any messages, there are two reasons: 
 (1) They are not valid users. Their names have not been added into the NT 
Web_GasTraders Group yet. Please contact Chrysti Hardy to add their names 
into the group.
 (2) There is no new messages added yet.

4) Click on "Comments" button to add messages: there will be a popup window 
when user clicks on "comments" button. There are two ways to send the 
messages after typing the 
messages into the text box:
 (1) just simply press enter to send the message. or
 (2) click on "send" button to send the message.

5) After the message has been sent, The message will be displayed on the main 
window immediately, the rest people who are online will get the new message 
in less than 30 seconds. This time can be reduced to as less as 1 second. 
However, I would not recommend to reduce the time interval less than 10 
second.  Because each time the browser refreshes the screen, the screen will 
be blink. Users don't want the screen blink every second while they read the 
messages.

6) All messages will be cleaned up daily at 6:00PM. If they like to clean 
them up later than 6:00PM, please let me know. I can reset the time.

Note: Right now the application is under test environment. If they like it, I 
will move it into production environment soon.

Let me know any feedbacks.

Thanks,

Fangming

Dear West,

We talked briefly on Monday about our commitment to a full work day at Enron.  If you are in the office, then please be prepared to contribute to the group for a full day.  Our schedule now calls for critical communication in the afternoons.  We need to know that each employee will be here every day to create the consistency needed to outperform the rest of the market.  

We want to remain as flexible as possible with all traders when it comes to an emergency, but remember that you have a commitment to Enron to contribute a full work day.  

Please organize your vacation on the west desk calendar with Ina and coordinate any early afternoon departures with Ina and myself.  Also, prepare to have your markets covered when you leave the office early.

Sincerely,

Mike

body:
<email>
From: Jessica Thompson <jthompson@schoolboard.ca>
To: Dr. Emily Nakamura <enakamura@university.ca>
Subject: Exploring a career change

Hi Emily,

I hope this email finds you well. It's been great keeping in touch since we met at the Indigenous education conference last year. I've been thinking a lot about our conversations and the work you're doing in anthropology, particularly around Indigenous education and cultural preservation.

I've been considering a career change and am interested in pursuing a path similar to yours. I'm passionate about adapting education to fit the unique needs of Indigenous students, and I believe that understanding the historical and cultural context is crucial to this work.

Would you be open to chatting further about your career journey and any advice you might have for someone like me who's considering a transition into anthropology? I'd love to learn from your experience and insights.

Best regards,
Jessica
label: research

theres only one thing i can think of...   storage field turning around gives 
cash market completely different feel.   instead of utilities looking to sell 
gas everday, they look to buy it.  huge difference in feel of mrket.  not so 
much actual gas but completely different economics of how marginal mmbtu gets 
priced.  tightening cash market causes cash players to buy futures... hence 
the tendency for a spring rally every year.  read heffner today...even he

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@oakwoodhigh.edu>
To: Michael Thompson <mthompson@oakwoodhigh.edu>
Subject: Upcoming Chemistry Education Conference

Hey Michael,

I hope you're doing well! I wanted to reach out because I noticed that we're both attending the Chemistry Education Conference in San Francisco next month. I'm really looking forward to learning about the latest teaching strategies and techniques to help our students better understand chemistry concepts.

I was wondering if you'd like to meet up for dinner one evening during the conference to discuss what we've learned and share our thoughts on how we can implement these ideas in our classrooms. I know we often collaborate on lesson plans, so I thought it might be a great opportunity to brainstorm together.

Let me know if you're interested, and if so, which day works best for you. I'm free any evening except for the last day of the conference.

Looking forward to seeing you in San Francisco!

Best,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Alex Thompson <alex.thompson@quantumexplorer.com>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@conservation.org>
Subject: RE: Invitation to participate in our upcoming seminar

Hi Emily,

Thank you for the invitation! I'm flattered that you consider my perspectives interesting. I would be delighted to participate in the seminar and share my thoughts on the intersection of physics and biology in conservation efforts.

I recently posted a theory in the group, attempting to connect quantum physics with the behavior of certain wildlife species. I would be curious to hear your thoughts on this idea and how it might relate to your work in conservation biology.

Looking forward to the seminar!

Best,
Alex

To: Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@history.edu>
Subject: RE: Catching up and a potential collaboration

Michael,

I'm so glad you're on board with this project! I appreciate you sharing your initial research findings. It's incredible to see how far we've come in terms of medical knowledge and treatment options.

I'm available next Tuesday afternoon or Thursday morning for a call. Let me know what works best for you, and we can start fleshing out the details of our proposal.

On a personal note, I wanted to thank you again for offering to mentor my daughter, Lily. She's really excited about the prospect of studying history in college, and your guidance means a lot to us.

Looking forward to our collaboration!

Best,
Emily

Hi Jenna,

Good to hear from you! I'm excited for the event and I think we've put together a really solid program. A few thoughts:

- The schedule looks perfect. The break in between should give us time to reset the stage and make sure everything's ready for the veteran portion.

- I took a look at the remarks and they're great! You've really captured the spirit of what we're trying to do. I made a few minor tweaks and added a line about the legacy of the Russian Empire's involvement in WWI, but otherwise it's excellent.

- I have the final RSVP list and will send it over today. I think we'll be at capacity, so we may need to add some extra chairs!

As for meeting up, I'm free Tuesday afternoon or Wednesday evening if that works for you. Let me know what time is best and I'll make the coffee! 

I really appreciate all the hard work you've put into this, Jenna. It's been a pleasure working with you and I know the attendees will be in for a treat.

Best,
Alexei

"George Richards" <cbpres@austin.rr.com> on 09/08/2000 05:21:49 AM
Please respond to <cbpres@austin.rr.com>
To: "Phillip Allen" <pallen@enron.com>
cc: "Larry Lewter" <retwell@mail.sanmarcos.net> 
Subject: Westgate Proforma-Phillip Allen.xls


Enclosed is the preliminary proforma for the Westgate property is Austin
that we told you about.  As you can tell from the proforma this project
should produce a truly exceptional return of over 40% per year over 3 years.
This is especially attractive when the project is in a market as strong as
Austin and we are introducing new product that in a very low price range for
this market.  This is the best project in terms of risk and reward that we
have uncovered to date in the Austin market.
The project does have approved zoning and will only require a site plan.  As
it is in the "Smart Growth Corridor" area designated by the City of Austin
for preferred development, this will be fast tracked and should be complete
in less than 6 months.  Additionally, many of the current and more severe
water treatment ordinances have been waived.  I have estimated the lot
improvement costs based on a 28 lot development we investigated in North
Austin, which included a detention/retention and filtration pond and street
widening.  Even though this property is not likely to require street
widening and will have less of a detention/retention and filtration pond
requirement, I used this data to be cautious.
 The Lone Star gas line easement in the lower portion of the property is not
expected to impact sales significantly.  Other projects have been quite
successful with identical relationships to this pipeline, such as the
adjoining single family residential and a project at St. Edwards University.
As with most infill projects, the quality of the surrounding neighborhoods
is uneven.  We have included a fence around the entire property, but may
only put it on Westgate and Cameron Loop.  Gated communities are far
preferred so this is a good idea for both screening and current buyer
preferences.
The seller accepted our offer Thursday evening with a price of $680,000 and
an extended escrow.  This will enable us to probably obtain an approved site
plan before closing on the contract, which will mean that we can close into
an A&D Loan rather than into a land loan and then an improvement loan.
This analysis shows your investment at $700,000 for a 50% interest in the
profits of the project.  As we discussed in San Marcos, we can also discuss
having you invest only in the lots, sell the lots to the construction entity
with your profit in the lot.  I believe this would facilitate the use of a
1031 Exchange of the proceeds from this deal into another project that is a
rental deal or at least into the land for a rental project that would then
be the equity for that project.  You would need to discuss this with an
exchange expert first.  Larry Lewter knows an expert in the field in San
Antonio if you do not know anyone.
I will send you a package on the property that was prepared by the broker,
by Airborne Express today for Saturday delivery.
Once you have read the package and reviewed this proforma, we would want to
schedule a tour of the site and the area.  Please get back to me as soon as
your schedule permits regarding the site visit and feel free to call at any
time.  You can reach me over the weekend and in the evening at either
512-338-1119 or 512-338-1110.  My cell phone is 512-748-7495 and the fax is
512-338-1103.   I look forward to hearing from you and to working with you
on this project that is sure to be a major winner.
I regret that it took so long to get back to you, but we had some unusual
events these past few weeks.  A small freakish wind storm with severe 60+mpg
downdrafts hit the South part of Austin where we are building 10 town homes.
One of these units had just had the roof decked with the siding scheduled to
start the next day.  The severe downdraft hitting the decked roof was enough
to knock it down.  The City shut down the project for a week and it took
another week to get every thing back on tract.  Then last week I had to take
my wife  to emergency.  She has a bulge in the material between the vertebra
in her spine and it causes her extreme pain and has kept her bedridden this
past week..  There is nothing like having your wife incapacitated to realize
the enormous number of things she does everyday.   Fortunately, it looks as
if she will be ok in the long run.
George W. Richards
Creekside Builders, LLC


 - Westgate Proforma-Phillip Allen.xls

Date: Tue, 10 Apr 2001 10:51:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: phillip.allen@enron.com
To: mike.grigsby@enron.com
Subject: CAISO demand reduction
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: Mike Grigsby
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_June2001\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

---------------------- Forwarded by Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT on 04/10/2001 
05:50 PM ---------------------------
   
	Enron North America Corp.
	
	From:  Stephen Swain                           04/10/2001 11:58 AM
	

To: Phillip K Allen/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc: Tim Heizenrader/PDX/ECT@ECT, Tim Belden/HOU/ECT@ECT, Matt 
Motley/PDX/ECT@ECT, Michael M Driscoll/PDX/ECT@ECT, Chris 
Mallory/PDX/ECT@ECT, Jeff Richter/HOU/ECT@ECT, Robert Badeer/HOU/ECT@ECT, 
Sean Crandall/PDX/ECT@ECT, Mark Fischer/PDX/ECT@ECT, Bill Williams 
III/PDX/ECT@ECT, Diana Scholtes/HOU/ECT@ECT 
Subject: CAISO demand reduction

Phillip et al.,

I have been digging into the answer to your question re: demand reduction in 
the West.  Your intuition as to reductions seen so far (e.g., March 2001 vs. 
March 2000) was absolutely correct.  At this point, it appears that demand 
over the last 12 months in the CAISO control area, after adjusting for 
temperature and time of use factors, has fallen by about 6%.  This translates 
into a reduction of about 1,500-1,600 MWa for last month (March 2001) as 
compared with the previous year.

Looking forward into the summer, I believe that we will see further voluntary 
reductions (as opposed to "forced" reductions via rolling blackouts).  Other 
forecasters (e.g., PIRA) are estimating that another 1,200-1,300 MWa (making 
total year-on-year reduction = 2,700-2,800) will come off starting in June.  
This scenario is not difficult to imagine, as it would require only a couple 
more percentage points reduction in overall peak demand.  Given that the 6% 
decrease we have seen so far has come without any real price signals to the 
retail market, and that rates are now scheduled to increase, I think that it 
is possible we could see peak demand fall by as much as 10% relative to last 
year.  This would mean peak demand reductions of approx 3,300-3,500 MWa in 
Jun-Aug.  In addition, a number of efforts aimed specifically at conservation 
are being promoted by the State, which can only increase the likelihood of 
meeting, and perhaps exceeding, the 3,500 MWa figure.  Finally, the general 
economic slowdown in Calif could also further depress demand, or at least 
make the 3,500 MWa number that much more attainable.

Note that all the numbers I am reporting here are for the CAISO control area 
only, which represents about 89% of total Calif load, or 36-37% of WSCC 
(U.S.) summer load.  I think it is reasonable to assume that the non-ISO 
portion of Calif (i.e., LADWP and IID) will see similar reductions in 
demand.  As for the rest of the WSCC, that is a much more difficult call.  As 
you are aware, the Pacific NW has already seen about 2,000 MWa of aluminum 
smelter load come off since Dec, and this load is expected to stay off at 
least through Sep, and possibly for the next couple of years (if BPA gets its 
wish).  This figure represents approx 4% of the non-Calif WSCC.  Several 
mining operations in the SW and Rockies have recently announced that they are 
sharply curtailing production.  I have not yet been able to pin down exactly 
how many MW this translates to, but I will continue to research the issue.  
Other large industrials may follow suit, and the ripple effects from Calif's 
economic slowdown could be a factor throughout the West.  While the rest of 
the WSCC may not see the 10%+ reductions that I am expecting in Calif, I 
think we could easily expect an additional 2-3% (on top of the 4% already 
realized), or approx 1,000-1,500 MWa, of further demand reduction in the 
non-Calif WSCC for this summer.  This would bring the total reduction for the 
WSCC, including the 2,000 MWa aluminum load we have already seen, to around 
6,500-7,000 MWa when compared with last summer.

I am continuing to research and monitor the situation, and will provide you 
with updates as new or better information becomes available.  Meantime, I 
hope this helps.  Please feel free to call (503-464-8671) if you have any 
questions or need any further information.

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@university.edu.au>
To: Michael Thompson <michael.thompson@historian.org>
Subject: Seeking your expertise on early colonial interactions

Dear Michael,

I hope this email finds you well. I'm reaching out to you because I'm currently working on a project that I think you might be able to help with. I'm researching the impact of European settlement on Indigenous Australian cultures, specifically focusing on the early colonial period. Given your extensive knowledge on maritime exploration and early Australian settlement, I was hoping you might be able to provide some insights or point me towards any relevant resources you've come across in your research.

I'm particularly interested in understanding the initial interactions between the First Fleet settlers and the Indigenous communities they encountered. Any information you could share would be greatly appreciated.

I look forward to hearing back from you.

Best regards,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: Michael Thompson <mthompson@oakvillehigh.edu>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@stargazer.edu>
Subject: RE: Guest Lecture on Astronomy and Geography

Dear Emily,

Thank you for reaching out with this exciting opportunity! I am thrilled to have a solar physics researcher interested in giving a guest lecture at our school. Your insights on the relationship between astronomy and geography would be a valuable addition to our curriculum.

I would be happy to discuss potential topics for your lecture and how we can integrate it into our geography lessons. Understanding the Earth's place in the universe is indeed crucial for our students' comprehension of the world around them.

As for the textbooks, I recommend "Physical Geography: A Landscape Appreciation" by Tom L. McKnight and Darrel Hess, and "Essentials of Geography" by Arthur Getis and Judith Getis. These books provide a comprehensive introduction to the field and cover a wide range of topics, from landforms and climate to human-environment interactions.

I am also intrigued by your interest in the history of scientific discoveries and how they have shaped our understanding of the world. This is a topic that I am passionate about, and I believe our students would greatly benefit from learning about the interconnectedness of scientific disciplines.

Perhaps we could explore the possibility of collaborating on a project to create educational materials that bridge the gap between astronomy and geography. I would love to hear your thoughts on this idea.

Looking forward to our further discussions!

Best regards,
Michael Thompson

body:
<email>
From: Alex Novak <alex.novak@stargazer.edu>
To: Dr. Lena Patel <lena.patel@bioinfo.org>
Subject: RE: Exciting collaboration opportunity

Lena,

Thank you for your enthusiastic response! I'm glad you're on board with this project. Your expertise in systems biology and bioinformatics will be invaluable in making this resource comprehensive and engaging.

I appreciate you taking the lead on the grant proposal. As we discussed, I'll focus on the astronomy aspects and ensure that the content is accurate and accessible to a wide audience.

Next Tuesday afternoon works well for me to have a call and discuss our next steps. Please feel free to send over a Zoom link or suggest a time that suits you best.

I'm eager to dive into this project and create something impactful together!

Best regards,
Alex
label: research

Subject: Credit Suisse First Boston

CSFB informed us today that their Appalachia hedging deal will likely happen 
in the next two weeks. The deal, in short, involves Enron buying an average 
volume of 11,500 mmBtu/d at TCO and 5,500 mmBtu/d at CNG for 12 years and 1 
month from Dec00. 
CSFB would like to get an idea of where the market is now. I've attached a 
spreadsheet that details the volumes, which decline with time. Could you 
please provide indicative prices, as of tonight's close. 
Thanks,
Russ

body:
<email>
From: Alex Chen <achen@university.edu>
To: Taylor Johnson <taylor.johnson@highschool.edu>
Subject: Re: Help with physics problem set

Hi Taylor,

I hope you're doing well! I noticed you've been struggling with the latest problem set on special relativity. If you'd like, we can go over the concepts together during my office hours this Friday. I'll be available from 3-5 pm in the physics building, room 212.

Also, I wanted to mention that I've been impressed with your enthusiasm and dedication to learning. If you're considering a career in physics, I'd be happy to provide some guidance and answer any questions you might have about college applications and potential career paths.

Let me know if you have any other questions or if there's anything else I can help you with!

Best regards,
Alex

body:
Message-ID: <485202.1075855727566.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Tue, 6 Feb 2001 01:01:00 -0800 (PST)
From: phillip.allen@enron.com
To: jsmith@austintx.com
Subject: 
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: jsmith@austintx.com
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_June2001\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

Jeff,

I am not willing to guarantee to refinance the 1st lien on the stage in 4 
years and drop the rate on both notes at that point to 8%.  There are several 
reasons that I won't commit to this.  Exposure to interest fluctuations, the 
large cash reserves needed, and the limited financial resources of the buyer 
are the three biggest concerns.  

What I am willing to do is lower the second note to 8% amortized over the 
buyers choice of terms up to 30 years.  The existing note does not come due 
until September 2009.  That is a long time.  The buyer may have sold the 
property.  Interest rates may be lower.  I am bending over backwards to make 
the deal work with such an attractive second note.  Guaranteeing to refinance 
is pushing too far.

Can you clarify the dates in the contract.  Is the effective date the day the 
earnest money is receipted or is it once the feasibility study is complete?

Hopefully the buyer can live with these terms.  I got your fax from the New 
Braunfels buyer.  If we can't come to terms with the first buyer I will get 
started on the list.

Email or call  me later today.

Phillip

From: Emily Nguyen <emily.nguyen@educotech.edu>
To: Raj Patel <raj.patel@electronixpro.com>
Subject: Following up from the conference

Hi Raj,

It was great meeting you at the Electrical Measurement and Instrumentation Conference last month. I really enjoyed our conversation about the latest trends in electrical measurement tools and how they can be applied in educational settings.

I was wondering if you might be available for a quick call sometime next week to discuss a troubleshooting problem I've been having with one of the circuits in my lab. It's a bit outside my area of expertise, and I thought you might have some insights to offer.

Let me know if you have any availability, and I'd be happy to schedule a call.

Best regards,
Emily

body:
<email>
From: Michael Green <michael.green@tropicalgardens.com>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@harmonyelementary.org>
Subject: RE: Community Garden Project Proposal

Hi Emily,

Thank you for the update. I'm thrilled to hear that our project has been recognized and that we have the opportunity to present at the education conference. I would be more than happy to collaborate with you on the presentation.

I think it's a great idea to share our experiences and discuss the challenges we faced. It would also be valuable to include data and testimonials from students and parents to support our claims about the benefits of outdoor learning.

Let's schedule a meeting to brainstorm ideas for the presentation and to divide the tasks. I'm available next week on Tuesday and Thursday afternoons.

Looking forward to working with you on this exciting project!

Best regards,
Michael
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@nyuhistorians.org>
To: Michael Thompson <mthompson@ucla.edu>
Subject: Upcoming Conference Panel

Dear Michael,

I hope this email finds you well. As you know, we have been invited to participate in a panel discussion at the upcoming history conference in Chicago. The topic of our presentation is the economic and social factors leading to the American Civil War.

I think it's a great opportunity for us to collaborate and share our expertise on this important subject. I was wondering if you have any initial thoughts on how we should structure our presentation and what key points we should cover.

I believe that combining our research on the 18th and 19th centuries will provide a comprehensive overview of the issues at hand. Perhaps we can start by outlining the main economic and social differences between the North and the South, and then discuss how these factors contributed to the growing tensions that ultimately led to the war.

Please let me know your thoughts, and if you have any specific ideas or suggestions for our presentation. I look forward to working with you on this exciting project.

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Sarah Thompson <sarah.thompson@tech.edu>
To: Dr. Alex Chen <alex.chen@genomeinstitute.org>
Subject: Collaborative project update

Hi Alex,

I hope you're doing well! I've been thinking a lot about our project and the upcoming conference. I'm excited to share our work with the education community, but I'm also feeling a bit overwhelmed by the complexity of some of the genetic concepts we're trying to include.

I was wondering if you could help me break down some of these ideas into more digestible pieces. I think it would be really valuable for our target audience (high school students) to have a solid understanding of the basic principles behind DNA sequencing and genetic analysis, but I'm not sure how to simplify it without losing the essential details.

Do you have any suggestions or resources that might help me grasp these concepts better? I'd really appreciate your input.

Looking forward to hearing from you!

Best,
Sarah
label: research

I'm free from 4:00-5:00 today


   
	
	
	From:  Vladimir Gorny                           07/10/2000 02:14 PM
	

To: John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECT
cc: Tanya Tamarchenko/HOU/ECT@ECT, Frank Hayden/Corp/Enron@Enron 
Subject: Forward-forward Vol

John,

Per your and Jeff's request, Research and Market Risk Groups have conducted 
an extensive analysis of the forward-forward vol methodology used in the 
Value-at-Risk calculation. 

We analyzed and compared two methodologies: 

 the existing methodology - based on forward (implied) vols
 an alternative methodology - based on historical vols

I would like to schedule about 30 minutes to walk you through the pros and 
cons of each methodology and get your input.

Vlady.

body:
<email>
From: Liam Nakamura <lnakamura@solarobs.com>
To: Olivia Thompson <othompson@astronomy.edu>
Subject: RE: Historical Solar Observations and Our Paper

Olivia,

That's a great idea! I'd be happy to contribute a section on modern solar observation techniques. In fact, I recently came across some intriguing data from the 1980s while going through the archives here at Mauna Loa. It's about a particularly strong solar flare and its impact on Earth's ionosphere. I think it could be a perfect case study for our paper.

I'm attaching the data I found. Let me know what you think, and we can discuss how to incorporate it into the paper.

Also, I'm looking forward to seeing you at the conference in San Diego! We should definitely arrange a time to meet up and go over our paper in person.

Best,
Liam
label: research

As required by the Houston Fire Department, a fire drill has been scheduled for the Enron Center Campus.


	Enron Center North, 1400 Smith St., approximately  3:15 PM on Thursday, December 20th, 2001

	Enron Center South, 1500 Louisiana St., approximately 3:45 PM on Thursday, December 20th, 2001

Please advise all clients, contractors, and visitors that this will be a fire drill only. The fire alarm will sound at 3:15 PM in Enron Center North and 3:45 PM in Enron Center South. You will be asked to go to the stairwell and standby.  Do not go into the stairwell.  Further instructions will be given over the public address system.  If you experience any difficulties in hearing either the fire alarm or any announcements over the public address system, please notify the Facilities Help Desk by e-mail at facilitieshelpdesk1@enron.com. 

Anyone that is mobility impaired or medically disabled may be excused from participating in this drill by sending an e-mail to Harry Grubbs. 

If you have any questions or need any additional information, please contact Harry Grubbs at 713-853-5417.

Larrry,

I realize you are disappointed about the project.  It is not my desire for 
you to be left with out of pocket expenses.  The only item from your list 
that I need further 
clarification is the $15,000 worth of extensions.  You mentioned that this 
was applied to the cost of the land and it actually represents your cash 
investment in the land.  I agree that you should be refunded any cash 
investment.  My only request is that you help me locate this amount on the 
closing statement or on some other document.

Phillip
label: corporate

body:
<email>
From: Liam Evans <levans@nationalweatherservice.gov>
To: Jordan Fisher <jfisher@nationalweatherservice.gov>
Subject: RE: Our research paper submission

Jordan,

That's a tough situation with the job offer from the private forecasting company. I completely understand your hesitation to leave the national weather service and our collaboration. It's a decision that could have a significant impact on both our professional and personal lives.

I think applying for a grant from the National Science Foundation is a great idea. If we can secure funding, it would allow us to continue our research here and maintain our close working relationship. I'm more than happy to help in any way I can with the application process.

I'm definitely free to grab a coffee and discuss this further. How about we meet at our usual spot, The Weathered Cup, this Friday afternoon? We can brainstorm strategies and start putting together a plan for our grant application.

Looking forward to seeing you then!

Best,
Liam
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Alex Rivera <arivera@underwater-heritage.org>
To: Jordan Lee <jlee@chem-research.edu>
Subject: Visiting your lab during my trip to Oakville

Hi Jordan,

I hope this email finds you well. I'm reaching out because I'll be visiting Oakville next month for a conference and was hoping to stop by your lab to learn more about the chemical analysis techniques you use in your research. I think there could be some exciting possibilities for collaboration between our fields.

Would any of these dates work for a visit? I'm flexible and can work around your schedule:

- Monday, May 15th
- Tuesday, May 16th
- Wednesday, May 17th

Please let me know if any of these dates would be convenient for you. I'm really looking forward to meeting you in person and discussing our research further.

Best regards,
Alex
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Olivia Nguyen <olivia.nguyen@techwriter.com>
To: Ethan Jennings <ethan.jennings@mail.com>
Subject: RE: Digitizing my stamp collection

Hi Ethan,

Thank you for reaching out! I'm glad you found my posts helpful. Digitizing a stamp collection is a great way to preserve and share your passion for philately. I recommend using a high-resolution scanner with a transparency adapter for scanning your stamps. As for organizing your digital collection, I suggest using a database software like MySQL or a content management system like WordPress with a custom plugin for collections.

I'd be happy to provide more detailed guidance if you need it. By the way, I'm always on the lookout for interesting stories related to technology and communication. If you have any anecdotes about your stamps or the history of postal services, I'd love to hear them!

Best,
Olivia
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily@cyberguardians.com>
To: David Thompson <david@datadeveloper.io>
Subject: Database Design for CyberGuardians Educational Platform

Dear David,

I hope this email finds you well. My name is Emily Johnson, and I am the founder of CyberGuardians, an educational platform that teaches children aged 8-14 about online safety, privacy, and digital citizenship.

I came across your profile on LinkedIn and was impressed by your expertise in database design and development. I am reaching out to you because I believe your skills and experience would be invaluable to our project.

At CyberGuardians, we aim to create an engaging and interactive platform that empowers young learners to navigate the digital world safely. As part of this initiative, we need a robust and secure database to store user information, track progress, and handle gamification elements like rewards and leaderboards.

I would love to schedule a call with you to discuss the project in more detail and explore the possibility of working together. Please let me know your availability in the coming week.

Thank you for considering our request, and I look forward to the opportunity to collaborate with you.

Best regards,
Emily Johnson
Founder, CyberGuardians
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Emily Nguyen <emily.nguyen@asianartmuseum.org>
To: James Lee <james.lee@buddhiststudies.com>
Subject: Seeking your expertise on a rare find

Dear James,

I hope this email finds you well. It's been a while since our last collaboration, and I've been meaning to catch up with you. I'm reaching out today because I could use your invaluable expertise on a new acquisition for our museum.

We recently obtained a fascinating Buddhist artifact that has left our team puzzled. It's a intricately carved wooden statue of the Buddha, but with some unusual iconography that we've never encountered before. I was hoping you might be able to shed some light on its origins and significance.

Would you be available for a call next week to discuss this further? I'd be happy to send you some images of the artifact beforehand.

Looking forward to hearing from you and hopefully working together again.

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Olivia Thompson <othompson@oakgroveacademy.com>
To: Emily Jacobs <ejacobs@westviewelementary.org>
Subject: RE: Great meeting you at the NAEA conference!

Hi Emily,

Thank you so much for your email and for sharing your lesson plans! I'm excited to take a closer look and incorporate some of your techniques into my own teaching.

I've been thinking a lot about our conversation and the challenges of providing quality art education to students from low-income backgrounds. It's something I'm really passionate about, and I believe that collaborating with other teachers is key to making a bigger impact.

I had an idea I wanted to run by you - what if we organized a virtual art show featuring students from both of our schools? We could have them create pieces inspired by the same theme or art movement and then display their work together online. Maybe we could even arrange some virtual meet-and-greets so the students can interact with each other.

Let me know what you think! I'd love to brainstorm further and potentially apply for a grant to help fund the project.

Best,
Olivia
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Alex Thompson <alex.thompson@email.com>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@email.com>
Subject: RE: Collaborating on a project

Hey Emily,

Wednesday at 4 PM works great for me. I'll add it to my calendar.

I like your idea of breaking the guide down into modules with interactive activities and quizzes. That should help keep students engaged and make the learning process more enjoyable. We can also consider including some hands-on projects that allow students to apply what they've learned.

I've been thinking about the technical aspects we should cover, and I've come up with a rough outline:

1. Introduction to computer hardware
2. CPU and processor basics
3. Memory (RAM and storage)
4. Motherboards and expansion cards
5. Power supply and cooling
6. Peripherals and input/output devices

We can definitely refine this further during our call and decide on the best way to present the information.

I'm also curious to know if you have any specific vocabulary-related activities in mind for each module. I think your expertise will be crucial in making the technical concepts more accessible.

Looking forward to our call next week!

Best,
Alex

body:
<email>
From: Alex Rivera <arivera@envirogeo.org>
To: Jordan Martinez <jmartinez@envirogeo.org>
Subject: Mapping project update

Hey Jordan,

I hope you're doing well. I wanted to touch base with you about the progress we've made on the climate change and geological events mapping project. We've managed to gather a significant amount of data on potential landslide and volcanic activity hotspots, and I think we're ready to start creating some preliminary maps.

I was wondering if you could take a look at the data we've collected and let me know if there are any historical mapping techniques that might be useful for visualizing this information. I'm particularly interested in any methods that could help us convey the potential impact of these events on human settlements in a clear and accessible way.

Let me know if you have any thoughts or suggestions. I'm excited to see what we can create together!

Best,
Alex

body:
<email>
From: Michael Rodriguez <michael.rodriguez@ridgemonthigh.edu>
To: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@oakvillehigh.edu>
Subject: RE: Help with electron configuration in molecular orbital theory

Hi Emily,

Thank you for bringing this up. I've definitely noticed the same issue in my classes, and I agree that we need to find a better way to explain electron configuration in the context of molecular orbital theory.

I've been doing some research, and I came across a few resources that might be helpful. There's a great video series by Professor XYZ from ABC University that breaks down electron configuration in a really clear and engaging way. I think we could use some of his explanations and visualizations in our simulations.

I also found a few interactive tools that allow students to manipulate electron configurations and see how they affect molecular orbitals in real-time. I think incorporating something like that into our project could be really beneficial for students' understanding.

What do you think? If you're interested, I can send you the links to the resources I found, and we can discuss how we might integrate them into our simulations.

Looking forward to your thoughts!

Best,
Michael
label: research

body:
<email>
From: James Thompson <jthompson@medtech.org>
To: Maria Rodriguez <mrodriguez@aquatica.org>
Subject: RE: Urgent: New fish weir discovery in Lake Titicaca

Maria,

This is truly remarkable! The photographs you've sent are fascinating, and I can already see the potential implications for our research. I agree that we must find a way to include this new information in our paper.

I have a few initial thoughts on how we might proceed:

1. We should prioritize the analysis of the new site and its features, focusing on how it compares to known pre-Columbian and medieval European fishing structures.

2. We may need to restructure some sections of our paper to accommodate this new information, particularly the introduction and conclusion.

3. I will reach out to the journal editor today to request a two-week extension, citing the significance of this new discovery. Hopefully, they will be understanding.

4. We should schedule a video call this week to discuss our revised strategy and divide tasks to ensure we meet the new deadline.

Please let me know if you have any other suggestions or concerns. I'm excited to work together on this groundbreaking research!

Best,
James
label: research

rules to a game:
You flip a coin. If you get tails you win 0.  if you get heads, i give you
$1.  Keep flipping until you get a tails, at which point you walk away with
the money.  however, each heads you get after the first you double your
money.  So if you flip heads 3 times and then tails, you get $4.  What's
you bid/offer on playing this game?  (would you pay $.5 to play? $1? $2?
what you charge me play against you?)

body:
<email>
From: Dr. Emily Nguyen <enguuyen@westford.edu>
To: Dr. Michael Thompson <mthompson@econanalysis.edu>, Dr. Olivia Patel <opatel@historyinsights.org>
Subject: Invitation to Participate in Panel Discussion

Dear Dr. Thompson and Dr. Patel,

I hope this email finds you well. My name is Dr. Emily Nguyen, and I am the chair of the interdisciplinary studies department at the University of Westford. We are organizing a conference titled "Historical Roots of Modern Inequalities: An Interdisciplinary Approach," which will take place on [date] at our campus.

I am writing to invite you both to participate in a panel discussion titled "The Economics of Inequality: Past and Present." Given your expertise in economics and history, respectively, we believe that your insights would be invaluable to our attendees. The panel will explore how economic policies and practices from the 19th century have shaped current economic disparities and social inequalities.

I have taken the liberty of introducing you to each other as fellow panelists. I hope that you will have the opportunity to discuss your ideas and prepare for the panel in the coming weeks.

Please let me know if you would be interested in participating. We would be honored to have you join us for this important conversation.

Best regards,
Dr. Emily Nguyen
