Phillip,

> As discussed  during our phone conversation, In a Parallon 75 microturbine
> power generation deal for a national accounts customer, I am developing a
> proposal to sell power to customer at fixed or collar/floor price. To do
> so I need a corresponding term gas price for same. Microturbine is an
> onsite generation product developed by Honeywell to generate electricity
> on customer site (degen). using natural gas. In doing so,  I need your
> best fixed price forward gas price deal for 1, 3, 5, 7 and 10 years for
> annual/seasonal supply to microturbines to generate fixed kWh for
> customer. We have the opportunity to sell customer kWh 's using
> microturbine or sell them turbines themselves. kWh deal must have limited/
> no risk forward gas price to make deal work. Therein comes Sempra energy
> gas trading, truly you.
>
> We are proposing installing 180 - 240 units across a large number of
> stores (60-100) in San Diego.
> Store number varies because of installation hurdles face at small percent.
>
> For 6-8 hours a day  Microturbine run time:
> Gas requirement for 180 microturbines 227 - 302 MMcf per year
> Gas requirement for 240 microturbines 302 - 403 MMcf per year
>
> Gas will likely be consumed from May through September, during peak
> electric period.
> Gas price required: Burnertip price behind (LDC) San Diego Gas & Electric
> Need detail breakout of commodity and transport cost (firm or
> interruptible).
>
> Should you have additional questions, give me a call.
> Let me assure you, this is real deal!!
>

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@rivertown.gov>
To: Alex Rivera <alex.rivera@historicdesigns.com>
Subject: Grand Opening Event Planning

Hi Alex,

I hope you're doing well! As we approach the completion of the Riverdale Community Center project, I wanted to touch base with you regarding the grand opening event. We've made tremendous progress, and I believe it's time to start planning the big reveal.

I was thinking we could hold the event on the weekend of June 15th, which would give us enough time to finalize the remaining details and ensure everything is perfect. What do you think about inviting some local officials, media, and community members to showcase the space and its features?

I'd love to hear your thoughts on the event planning and any suggestions you might have. Let's touch base early next week to discuss further and divide up the tasks.

Best regards,
Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Jordan Lee <jlee@chem-research.edu>
To: Alex Rivera <arivera@underwater-heritage.org>
Subject: RE: Visiting your lab during my trip to Oakville

Hi Alex,

It's great to hear from you! I'd be more than happy to have you visit my lab during your trip to Oakville. Your research on ancient aquatic structures is fascinating, and I'm excited to explore potential collaborations.

Tuesday, May 16th, would be perfect for a lab visit. I can give you a tour and introduce you to my team. We can also discuss how our research might intersect and brainstorm ideas for future projects.

Please let me know if you have any specific topics or techniques you'd like to discuss during your visit. I'm happy to prepare any materials or demonstrations in advance.

I look forward to seeing you next month!

Best,
Jordan

See you next Tuesday!

Best,
Michael

Cary,

Here is the picture of the house I have in mind.  I was going for a simple
farmhouse style to  place on 5 acres near Wimberley.

A few points that might not be obvious from the plans are:

There will be a double porch across the back just like the front
No dormers (Metal roof)
1/2 bath under stairs
Overall dimensions are 55 by 40


What I am looking for is a little design help in the kitchen.  More
cabinets, maybe a different shaped island, and a way to enlarge the pantry.
Reagan
suggested that I find a way to make the exterior more attractive.  I want
to keep a simple roof line to avoid leaks, but I was thinking about
bringing the left
side forward in the front of the house and place 1 gable in the front.
That might look good if the exterior was stone and stucco.  Also the front
porch would
be smaller.

I have 3 bids from builders all around $325,000.  I am ready to go ahead
and have the plans done so I can spec out all the finishings and choose a
builder.
I just wanted to give you the opportunity to do the work.  As I mentioned
my alternative is $0.60/ft.  I thought that since I had a such a detailed
sketch, you might consider the job for less than the $6,000 that Reagan
allowed.

Phillip Allen
713-853-7041

body:
<email>
From: Alex Thompson <athompson@westfieldhigh.edu>
To: Emily Johnson <ejohnson@westfieldhigh.edu>
Subject: RE: Extra help with molecular orbital theory

Mrs. Johnson,

Thank you so much for your email. I really appreciate you taking the time to help me understand this material better. I've been feeling pretty anxious about the upcoming test and struggling to grasp the concepts.

I would love to take a look at that online resource you mentioned. Interactive visualizations sound like they could be really helpful for me to see the connections between molecular orbitals and the periodic table.

If you have time, I would definitely appreciate going over it together. I want to do well on this test and feel more confident in my understanding of chemistry.

Thank you again for your help and support. It means a lot to me.

Best,
Alex Thompson

body:
<email>
From: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@oakridge.edu>
To: David Thompson <david.thompson@oakridge.edu>
Subject: Chemistry + Art Project

Hey David,

I've been thinking more about our chemistry and art project, and I'm really excited to get started! I think it's a great opportunity for our students to learn about the science behind color and chemical reactions while also expressing their creativity.

I was wondering if you had any thoughts on what specific chemical reactions we could use for the project? I'm thinking we could do something with pH indicators or maybe even a volcano-like reaction. Let me know what you think!

Also, I wanted to set up a time for us to meet and discuss the logistics of the project. I'm free this Friday after school if that works for you.

Looking forward to working together on this!

Emily
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Alex Thompson <alex.thompson@spaceenthusiast.com>
To: Emily Johnson <emily.johnson@pinevillehigh.edu>
Subject: RE: Exciting developments in gene editing!

Hey Emily,

Great to hear from you! I'm thrilled to learn about the advancements in gene editing technology. It's fascinating to think about the potential implications for space exploration and the search for extraterrestrial life.

Speaking of which, I recently attended a lecture by Dr. Sarah Miller, a prominent astrophysicist. She discussed the latest advancements in telescopic technology and how it's enabling us to detect potentially habitable exoplanets. It's an exciting time for sure!

I've been thinking about the upcoming World Science Conference in Denver. Would you be interested in attending? It covers various fields, including genetics and astrophysics. It could be a great opportunity to catch up in person and attend some sessions together.

Let me know what you think!

Best,
Alex
label: research

body:
<email>
From: Alex Rivera <arivera@pollinatorpower.org>
To: Emily Jennings <ejennings@radiationresponse.org>
Subject: RE: Follow-up from the community event

Hi Emily,

Thank you for reaching out! I'm glad you enjoyed the presentation and found the connection between pollinator conservation and community resilience compelling. I completely agree that combining our expertise could lead to some fantastic outreach opportunities.

I'm particularly excited about the idea of creating educational programs for local schools. Empowering the younger generation with knowledge about disaster preparedness and the importance of pollinators is crucial for building a more resilient and sustainable future.

I would love to chat next week to brainstorm ideas and discuss potential collaborations. Tuesday afternoon works well for me. How about we meet at the Green Leaf Café at 2 pm? It's a great spot for brainstorming sessions, and they have an excellent selection of pollinator-friendly beverages!

Looking forward to our collaboration,
Alex Rivera
Outreach Coordinator
Pollinator Power Initiative

body:
<email>
From: Jane Doe <jdoe@example.com>
To: John Smith <jsmith@example.com>
Subject: RE: Help with C programming questions

Hi John,

I'm glad to hear from you! I'm doing well, thanks for asking. I have some experience with pointers and memory allocation in Java and Python, but I'm not as familiar with C. However, I'd be happy to try and help you with your questions. Can you give me some specific examples of the problems you're having?

In the meantime, I'll do some research and see if I can find any good resources on the topic. I'll let you know if I find anything useful.

By the way, how is your programming project coming along? I remember you mentioned working on a game in your last email. I'd love to hear more about it.

Best regards,
Jane
label: research

body:
Message-ID: <10332688.1075855724986.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Wed, 4 Apr 2001 07:43:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: phillip.allen@enron.com
To: rlehmann@yahoo.com
Subject: Re: Answers to List
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: "Reagan Lehmann" <rlehmann@yahoo.com> @ ENRON
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_June2001\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

Thanks for the response.  I think you are right that engaging an architect is 
the next logical step.  I had already contacted Cary Kipp and sent him the 
floor plan.
He got back to me yesterday with his first draft.  He took my plan and 
improved it.  I am going to officially engage Cary to draw the plans.  While 
he works on those I wanted to try and work out a detailed specification 
list.  Also, I would like to visit a couple of homes that you have built and 
speak to 1 or 2 satisfied home owners.  I will be in San Marcos on Friday 
April 13th.  Are there any homes near completion that I could walk through 
that day?  Also can you provide some references?

Once I have the plans and specs, I will send them to you so you can adjust 
your bid.  

Phillip
label: Other

body:
<email>
From: Jordan Smith <jordan.smith1234@highschool.edu>
To: Mr. Michael Thompson <mthompson@elementaryschool.edu>
Subject: RE: Help with chemistry homework

Thank you so much for the resources, Mr. Thompson! I really appreciate you taking the time to help me out. The Khan Academy videos were really helpful for understanding the periodic table better. 

I do have a couple specific questions about the worksheet if you have a minute:

1. How do I know which elements will form ionic or covalent bonds?
2. What's the difference between single, double, and triple bonds?
3. How do I know how many electrons each element will gain or lose?

If you have any tips for those questions, that would be a huge help. Thank you again for all your help!

Best,
Jordan
label: research

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Bcc: mike.grigsby@enron.com
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: Ned Higgins <Ned Higgins/ENRON@enronXgate@ENRON>
X-cc: Mike Grigsby <Mike Grigsby/HOU/ECT@ECT>
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \PALLEN (Non-Privileged)\Allen, Phillip K.\Sent Items
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: PALLEN (Non-Privileged).pst

Ned,

Regarding the Waha storage, the west desk does not have a strong need for this storage but we are always willing to show a bid based on the current summer/winter spreads and cycling value.  The following assumptions were made to establish our bid:  5% daily injection capacity, 10% daily withdrawal capacity, 1% fuel (injection only), 0.01/MMBtu variable injection and withdrawal fees.  Also an undiscounted  June 01 to January 02 spread of $0.60 existed at the time of this bid.

Bid for a 1 year storage contract beginning June 01 based on above assumptions:  $0.05/ MMBtu/Month ($0.60/Year).  Demand charges only.

I am not sure if this is exactly what you need or not.  Please call or email with comments.

Phillip Allen

body:
Message-ID: <31434120.1075855688116.JavaMail.evans@thyme>
Date: Wed, 20 Sep 2000 06:34:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: phillip.allen@enron.com
To: cbpres@austin.rr.com
Subject: 
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-From: Phillip K Allen
X-To: cbpres@austin.rr.com
X-cc: 
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Phillip_Allen_Dec2000\Notes Folders\'sent mail
X-Origin: Allen-P
X-FileName: pallen.nsf

George,

 Below is a list of questions that Keith and I had regarding the Westgate 
project:

 Ownership Structure

 What will be the ownership structure? Limited partnership? General partner?

 What are all the legal entities that will be involved and in what 
capacity(regarding ownership and 
 liabilities)?

 Who owns the land? improvements?

 Who holds the various loans?

 Is the land collateral?

 Investment
 
 What happens to initial investment?

 Is it used to purchase land for cash?Secure future loans?
 
 Why is the land cost spread out on the cash flow statement?

 When is the 700,000 actually needed? Now or for the land closing? Investment 
schedule?

 Investment Return

 Is Equity Repayment the return of the original investment?

 Is the plan to wait until the last unit is sold and closed before profits 
are distributed?

 Debt

 Which entity is the borrower for each loan and what recourse or collateral 
is associated with each 
 loan?

 Improvement

 Construction

 Are these the only two loans?  Looks like it from the cash flow statement.

 Terms of each loan?

 Uses of Funds

 How will disbursements be made?  By whom?

 What type of bank account?  Controls on max disbursement? Internet viewing 
for investors?

 Reports to track expenses vs plan?

 Bookkeeping procedures to record actual expenses?

 What is the relationship of Creekside Builders to the project?  Do you get 
paid a markup on subcontractors as a 
 general contractor and paid gain out of profits?

 Do you or Larry receive any money in the form of salary or personal expenses 
before the ultimate payout of profits?

 Design and Construction
 
 When will design be complete?

 What input will investors have in selecting design and materials for units?

 What level of investor involvement will be possible during construction 
planning and permitting?

 Does Creekside have specific procedures for dealing with subcontractors, 
vendors, and other professionals? 
 Such as always getting 3 bids, payment schedules, or reference checking?

 Are there any specific companies or individuals that you already plan to 
use? Names?

These questions are probably very basic to you, but as a first time investor 
in a project like this it is new to me.  Also, I want to learn as
much as possible from the process.

Phillip
label: research

body: Dear OAA, I wanted to know when the DS timings and registrations shall open for monsoon semester? Regards, Yasha
label: student

body:
<email>
From: Oliver Reed <oliver.reed@oakwoodhigh.edu>
To: Emily Thompson <emily.thompson@oakwoodhigh.edu>
Subject: RE: Interdisciplinary Project Update

Hi Emily,

I'm so glad you reached out! I've been equally excited about our project and the potential impact it could have on our students. I'd love to meet up on Saturday afternoon to discuss our next steps. The local café sounds perfect – let's say 2 pm?

I've been thinking about the National Education Conference and how we can best present our findings. I think it's crucial that we emphasize the practical applications of our work and how it can help students navigate the complex world of politics and decision-making. What do you think?

I'll see you on Saturday!

Best,
Oliver
label: research
